STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 20, 2023
Chad Hannahs
Ingham County DHHS
5303 S. Cedar St.
Lansing, MI, 48911-3800
Re: License #: CP330201190
Dear Mr. Hannahs:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
10/18/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at .
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP330201190
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling
Chief Administrator: Chad Hannahs
Name of Agency: Ingham County DHHS
Agency Address: 5303 S. Cedar St.
Lansing, MI 48911-3800
Agency Telephone #: (517)887-9791
Original Issuance Date: 10/01/1991

homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
(2)An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child’s
placement at least once every month.
One of eight foster care files was missing one monthly foster home visit.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/17/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 12/2/2022 (previously cited as 12421(1,b)
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1)An agency’s medical and dental care policy must
include all the following: (f)A dental re-examination must
be obtained at least every 9 months unless a greater
frequency is indicated.
One of eight foster care files was missing a dental exam.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5)An agency shall involve the child’s parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster parents
to understand the plan for the child and the parents’ and
the foster parent’s role in assisting the agency in carrying
out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and review
2

the parent agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the information in
the parent-agency treatment plan and any other
information about the child and the child’s family is
confidential.
One of twenty-nine treatment plans did not have a foster parent signature to indicate
the foster parent was included in development of the plan or received a copy of it.
FOM 722-06B Family team meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
• Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
• Within 30 calendar days after the child’s 14th
birthday and every six months thereafter.
Two of eight foster care files did not meet FTM requirements.
One file did not have an FTM documented within 30 days prior to one updated
service plan.
The second file did not have an FTM documented within 30 days prior to three
updated service plans. The same file also did not have a semi-annual transition plan
completed within 30 days of the youth turning 14.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/17/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 12/2/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following area:
• Volunteer qualifications- Rule 206 (4) requires CPS clearances to be
completed prior to unsupervised contact with children. Clearances must be
available on-site for review by DCWL.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
3

There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. One special evaluation was completed by the agency on 4/17/23. The
special evaluation determined the foster home was in violation of rules 9403 Foster
Parent Duties and 9404 Behavior Management. It was determined the foster parent
engaging in rough horse play with a child who interpreted this play as unsafe, due
to their history of trauma. In addition, the foster parent used talk of the Boogyman to
influence the child's behavior. The agency recommended a 1st provisional license.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted one acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period.The CAP, approved 12/2/22, was a result of the 11/17/22 renewal
evaluation. During that review, the agency had fourteen violations regarding
service plans, home visits, missing placement information, independent living
documentation, borrowed beds, signatures on reports, family team meetings,
medical passports, medical exams, case contact entry, and action summaries.
During the current review, only four violations were found. Two of which are repeat
violations. Overall, the agency has demonstrated significant improvement and
compliance with their 2022 CAP.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment (CAA) indicated some barriers during the
previous year. One barrier was staffing difficulties. Specifically, that six foster care
staff left within a short time frame. In addition, two foster care supervisors were on
extended leave of absence, which resulted in one supervisor resigning. The
agency was not permitted to hire another supervisor at that time. Due to these
vacancies, case reassignments occurred, which causes some inconsistencies in
case management. The CAA further reported their experienced, lead worker, has
had to carry a full caseload due to the vacancies. Resulting in the lead worker
having less time to mentor new staff.
The CAA further reported the statewide placement crisis as an ongoing challenge,
with staff spending a significant amount of time, and making extraordinary efforts,
to prevent youth staying in the office or in a shelter. The agency has utilized
borrowed bed agreements of Temporary Placement Provider (TPP) homes from
other counties as one resource. The agency reported they continue to recruit new
foster homes, but recruitment has been a slow process. Licensing staff have also
struggled with the statewide implementation of a new computer system, CWLM.
Several help desk tickets have been processed due to needed data fixes and
processes not functioning as expected, which has delayed completion of some
licensing activities.
Despite these challenges, the CAA reported the agency has been successful in
implementation of the CAP and shown improvement in all areas. The CAA
identified increased supervisory oversight and protected time for staff as
successful strategies to maintain CAP compliance.
Financial Overview
No financial concerns were noted.
4

Staff Interviews
Two staff, one licensing worker and one foster care worker, were interviewed. The
foster care worker stated the agency was understaffed at times this year, which
resulted in her briefly taking extra cases to help. The worker did not mind helping
and felt supported. The foster care worker reported her supervisor is excellent
overall. The worker did not have any concerns about the agency. However, she
did note there were some issues with timely case assignments. When cases are
not assigned quickly, the workers struggle to meet the five-day timeframe to
complete certain tasks. The worker discussed this concern with her supervisor.
Otherwise, the worker stated she was very happy with and enjoy her job.
The licensing worker reported several changes this year with the implementation
of the CWLM computer system and new licensing rules. She reported this can be
challenging at times, but her supervisor has been helpful and supportive. The
worker noted she appreciates her supervisor’s ability to provide assistance and
also accept feedback from staff. The worker stated that recruitment of new homes
continues to be a challenge. However, they continue to partner with another
agency for recruitment activities and utilize the foster parent portal that was rolled
out earlier this year. The worker reported being satisfied with her job overall. One
area that she believes could be improved is utilizing CWLM to create reminders
(ticklers) for all of the licensing deadlines that have been established through
policy/procedure.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the same office building as the 2022
review. The building has sufficient space for staff and clients. There is adequate
locked storage for confidential materials.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified three safety concerns as follows:
Safety Alert 1: A visit was completed at the relative caregiver's home on 8/31/23. It
was noted the electrical outlets did not have covers. The relative was caring for a
toddler.
Resolution: On 9/1/23 the agency completed a home visit and confirmed outlet
covers had been installed throughout the home. Photos were provided to DCWL for
verification. Agency staff had a conversation with the relative about the importance
of ensuring the outlet covers remain in place and redirecting the child if they attempt
to touch them.
Safety Alert 2: A visit was completed at the relative caregiver's home on 9/11/23. It
was noted the family did not have a flotation device for their pool. Door alarms by the
pool and smoke detectors throughout the house were missing. The relative reported
the agency provided smoke detectors and door alarms, but they were removed
during a recent remodel.
Resolution: The agency visited the home on 9/12/23 and verified the flotation
device had been returned to the location by the pool, door alarms were provided by
5

the agency and installed, and smoke detectors were observed to be installed and
working. Photos were provided to DCWL for verification.
Safety Alert 3: A visit was completed at the licensed foster home on 9/12/23. It was
noted the door leading to the hot tub did not have an alarm and the hot tub cover did
not have locking latches.
Resolution: On 9/13/23 the agency visited the home and provided door alarms.
The alarms were immediately installed, and photos provided to DCWL for
verification. On 9/15/23 locking safety straps were installed into each side of the hot
tub cover to prevent it from being opened. Photos were provided to DCWL for
verification.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
_ ___________October 20, 2023________________________
Heather A Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 20, 2023
